lines.text: Yeah
I've been tryna call

annotations.text:
The first line of this song represents Abel’s vulnerability. A theme explored throughout the rest of this song. On the song “Coming Down,” Abel expresses very similar feelings:

Pick up your phone
The party’s finished and I want you to know
I’m all alone

Without drugs, Abel feels a sense of loneliness. This is perhaps Abel’s truest and most authentic self.

lines.text: I've been on my own for long enough

annotations.text:
Abel’s been on his own since around the age of 17 when he dropped out of high school and left home to never come back. This is referenced on many of his songs, like “Rolling Stone,” from his mixtape Thursday, where he said:

‘Cause I’ve been on these streets way too long, too long, too long
Baby, I’ve been on this too long

He’s also implying that he has been single for quite some time now and has forgotten how to love. From 2015 to 2019 Abel and model Bella Hadid had an on and off relationship, and after spending a few months apart, Abel seems to have lost his ability to love.

To add on, throughout After Hours, Abel plays with the idea of being “alone together” or simply “alone” on songs like “Save Your Tears”, “Faith,” and the opening track “Alone Again:”

‘Cause I don’t know if I can be alone again
I don’t know if I can be alone again

lines.text: Maybe you can show me how to love, maybe

annotations.text: maybe you can show me how to love , maybe

lines.text: I'm goin' through withdrawals

annotations.text:
A “withdrawal” can both mean the behavior in which one prefers to be alone or also the physical and mental effects experienced when a person stops using a drug. Considering Abel’s historic of drug abuse, which is largely mentioned in his songs, the second one is more likely.

Moreover, in a 2016 interview with The Guardian he referred to the subject:

When I had nothing to do but make music, it was very heavy. Drugs were a crutch for me.

lines.text: You don't even have to do too much

annotations.text: Abel may be talking about opiate withdrawal. During opiate withdrawal, your body is extremely sensitive. Because of this, even the slightest touch could turn him on.

lines.text: You can turn me on with just a touch, baby

annotations.text:
Abel expresses his great sensitivity towards the girl he’s with to show he’s really in love with her, or that he clings to every sign of affection, following what he says in the verse.

Also, even if that mustn’t be the same person he’s talking about in this track, Abel is not unfamiliar with this kind of touch. That could imply a reminiscence of feelings he had in his (fictional) past life, and the fact that he’s very sensitive towards women, and has always been.

This idea is somewhat confirmed in the chorus.

lines.text: I look around and

annotations.text:
Las Vegas is nicknamed “Sin City” due to the city’s overwhelming presence of crime, drugs, and sexual promiscuity—all important themes throughout The Weeknd’s career. He also explores hedonism on his August 2011 song “Heaven or Las Vegas.”

Abel experienced emptiness and heartbreak when he was briefly separated from Bella Hadid in 2019. The two have since reunited and emotionally completed The Weeknd.

Abel previously touched upon his need for Bella on his November 2019 single, “Heartless”:

You just came back in my life
You never gave up on me (Why don’t you?)
I’ll never know what you see (Why won’t you?)
I don’t do well when alone (Oh yeah)

lines.text: Sin City's cold and empty (Oh)
No one's around to judge me (Oh)
I can't see clearly when you're gone
I said, ooh, I'm blinded by the lights

annotations.text:
This song directly follows the outro of “Faith,” where The Weeknd speaks about being in the back of a police car presumably after an overdose:

I ended up in the back of a flashing car
With the city shining on my face
The lights are blinding me again

The “lights” here not only represent the lights from the police car or the city but also the fame Abel’s enjoyed for his recording career. From stage lights to paparazzi camera flashes, he’s been “blinded” by many examples of a wealthy and successful life, and he doesn’t plan on stopping anytime soon. However, his celebrity life often overshadows his deep personal life. On his 2018 song “Privilege,” Abel discusses how many fans and media sources didn’t believe that he could have a real and genuine relationship with a partner because of his status in fame:

They said our love is just a game, I don’t care what they say

Nevertheless, his relationship seems to be real and sound, as he claims that it is the only thing that can keep him peacefully inserted in this lifestyle.

Abel also uses a similar line on “Snowchild,” the fifth track from After Hours:

Leaving, leaving into the night
Now a nigga leaving, leaving
Leaving into the night, oh

lines.text: No, I can't sleep until I feel your touch (Touch)
I said, ooh, I'm drowning in the night
Oh, when I'm like this, you're the one I trust
Hey, hey, hey
I'm running out of time

annotations.text:
This line has several meanings:

First, he alludes to Las Vegas again. As mentioned in the pre-chorus of the song, Abel has a special emotional connection to the city. He recalls it here and automatically combines it with the chorus:

No, I can’t sleep until I feel your touch

Furthermore, Vegas is a city, known for being “alive” at night. Another reason this song’s story, or the whole album takes place in Vegas are Abel’s
repeated references of it, adding to the fact, that he feels at home there.

Abel fears, that he won’t be able to sleep, because he lost his loved one and needs to get her back to finally get sleep. At the end of his journey, he recalls this line. On “Final Lullaby”, the last track off the deluxe version of his album After Hours, Abel tries to accept the fact that he won’t find his love back in that night.

I’m running out of time
And you’ll always be on my mind

Another explanation could be his habit to be awake late at night, as already mentioned in “Alone Again”:

I’m falling only for the night

A possible reason for him being stressed during the day is his fame and popularity. During the day, Abel is blinded by the lights of police cars, but also by flashing camera lights, representing fame. Therefore, he likes to escape into the night, just like in his record “Snowchild”:

Leaving, leaving into the night
Now a nigga leaving, leaving
Leaving into the night, oh

lines.text: 'Cause I can see the sun light up the sky
So I hit the road in overdrive, baby, oh

annotations.text:
Here, Abel alludes to his habit of driving over the speed limit, which he has mentioned in several songs in the past, such as on “Heartless,”“ featured on his fourth studio album, After Hours:

I’ve been dodgin' death in the six-speed

Abel also admits his love for dangerous speeding on his September 2016 single “Starboy”

100 on the dash get me close to God

“Blinding Lights” was also originally teased in a German Mercedes-Benz commercial, where The Weeknd is shown driving an electric car while the song plays in the background.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97eZHGbaGZQ

lines.text: No, I can't sleep until I feel your touch (Touch)
I said, ooh, I'm drowning in the night
Oh, when I'm like this, you're the one I trust
I'm just coming back to let you know (Back to let you know)

annotations.text: This line is very similar to the song “Heartless,” released just days before this song. Here, Abel describes how his love for whom is presumed to be Bella Hadid is much stronger than he can say on the phone to her. This is different than the feelings Abel has shown in previous albums, with his typical themes usually revolving around never showing love towards anyone he is with and only using them for sex.

lines.text: I could never say it on the phone (Say it on the phone)
Will never let you go this time (Ooh)
I said, ooh, I'm blinded by the lights
